Expectation1: Be considerate with shared spaces and boundaries
Situation1: My dog becomes vocal in the hallway when people pass near shared doors.
Expectation2: Fix bugs and troubleshoot issues reported by users or QA
Situation2: A production outage traces back to a defect in their code and customers cannot access the service
Story: I was hunched over my laptop, sweat prickling my forehead as error logs scrolled endlessly across the screen. The outage alert had come in just as I was about to take my dog for a quick walk. Now, customers were locked out of the service, and my manager’s messages kept pinging: “Any update? ETA?” My fingers flew over the keyboard, searching for the bug that had brought everything down. Suddenly, a sharp bark echoed from the hallway—my dog, again, reacting to footsteps near the shared door. I winced, remembering the last complaint from Mrs. Lee next door about the noise. I could almost hear her sigh through the wall. I knew I should go out, calm my dog, and show I cared about our shared space. But the outage was urgent, and every second counted. My mind spun between the angry emails piling up and the neighborly expectations I was failing. I felt trapped, torn between the code demanding my attention and the neighborly decency I owed to those living just a few feet away.
